name: Goblin

traits.name: Nimble Escape
traits.desc: The goblin can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

actions.name: Scimitar
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) slashing damage.

actions.name: Shortbow
actions.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) piercing damage.

tactics: Goblins are cowards that fight in packs. They ambush from hiding (use their +6 Stealth!), fire arrows from cover, and use Nimble Escape to Hide again. If they lose half their number, survivors flee. Have their boss threaten them to keep fighting — it creates drama!
dmTips: Perfect starter enemies. Use groups of 3-5. Have them set simple traps (pit traps, tripwires with bells). Give their leader a name and a funny personality quirk to make the encounter memorable.

name: Skeleton
languages: Understands languages it knew in life but can't speak

actions.name: Shortsword
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) piercing damage.

actions.name: Shortbow
actions.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) piercing damage.

tactics: Skeletons follow orders mindlessly. They charge in a line, attack the nearest target, and never retreat. They're most dangerous when commanded by a necromancer who can direct them strategically.
dmTips: Great for atmosphere! Describe them rising from the ground or stepping out of coffins. Remind players about bludgeoning vulnerability — it makes fighters with maces feel awesome. Mix with a zombie or two for variety.

name: Wolf

traits.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
traits.desc: The wolf has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

traits.name: Pack Tactics
traits.desc: The wolf has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the wolf's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.

actions.name: Bite
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (2d4 + 2) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 11 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

tactics: Wolves always hunt in packs (3-6). They use Pack Tactics to gain advantage, and try to knock targets prone so the rest of the pack can pile on. They circle prey and one will try to lure the party forward while others flank.
dmTips: A pack of wolves is a great random encounter. The prone-on-hit mechanic teaches new players about conditions. If the party is struggling, have the wolves retreat to howl for reinforcements — it builds tension without being unfair.

name: Bandit

actions.name: Scimitar
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) slashing damage.

actions.name: Light Crossbow
actions.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d8 + 1) piercing damage.

tactics: Bandits prefer to outnumber their targets. They'll demand surrender and valuables first — fighting is bad for business. If combat starts, they try to take down the weakest-looking party member first.
dmTips: Bandits are PEOPLE, not mindless monsters. Give the leader a name, a motive, and maybe a sympathetic backstory. Maybe they're desperate refugees, or locals forced into crime by an oppressive lord. This creates moral complexity for your players.

name: Zombie
languages: Understands languages it knew in life but can't speak

traits.name: Undead Fortitude
traits.desc: If damage reduces the zombie to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zombie drops to 1 hit point instead.

actions.name: Slam
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) bludgeoning damage.

tactics: Zombies are slow but relentless. They shamble toward the nearest living creature. Undead Fortitude makes them surprisingly hard to put down — they keep getting back up! Focus fire is needed.
dmTips: Zombies are terrifying when they won't stay dead. Describe them getting back up dramatically. Use in tight corridors where their slow speed doesn't matter. Mix with skeletons for a classic undead encounter.

name: Giant Spider
senses: Blindsight 10 ft., Darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 10

traits.name: Spider Climb
traits.desc: The spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

traits.name: Web Sense
traits.desc: While in contact with a web, the spider knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.

traits.name: Web Walker
traits.desc: The spider ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

actions.name: Bite
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) piercing damage, and the target must make a DC 11 Constitution saving throw, taking 9 (2d8) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

actions.name: Web (Recharge 5-6)
actions.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, range 30/60 ft., one creature. Hit: The target is restrained by webbing. As an action, the restrained target can make a DC 12 Strength check, bursting the webbing on a success.

tactics: Giant spiders ambush from ceilings or wait in webs. They web one target first (preferably the healer or wizard), then bite restrained victims. They retreat to their webs if outnumbered.
dmTips: Set the scene with webs everywhere. Describe the sticky strands, cocooned remains of previous victims, and the skittering in the dark. The poison + restraint combo makes this a great 'teaching' monster for saving throws.

name: Kobold

traits.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
traits.desc: While in sunlight, the kobold has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

traits.name: Pack Tactics
traits.desc: The kobold has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the kobold's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.

actions.name: Dagger
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d4 + 2) piercing damage.

actions.name: Sling
actions.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d4 + 2) bludgeoning damage.

tactics: Kobolds NEVER fight fair. They use elaborate traps, ambushes from murder holes, and sheer numbers. They claim to serve a dragon (sometimes truthfully). When losing, they beg, plead, and offer to betray their leader.
dmTips: Kobolds are fun because they're clever cowards. Design a dungeon FULL of traps — pit traps, falling rocks, swinging blades. The kobolds use their small size and Pack Tactics to gang up on anyone who survives the gauntlet.

name: Orc

traits.name: Aggressive
traits.desc: As a bonus action, the orc can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

actions.name: Greataxe
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (1d12 + 3) slashing damage.

actions.name: Javelin
actions.desc: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) piercing damage.

tactics: Orcs charge headlong into battle using Aggressive to close distance immediately. They target the biggest, most armored opponent first to prove their strength. An orc war chief will direct combat while the grunts rush in.
dmTips: Orcs hit hard for their CR. A group of 4 orcs can seriously threaten a level 1-2 party. Use them as the muscle behind a smarter villain, or create a war-band with personality and internal power struggles.

name: Bugbear

traits.name: Brute
traits.desc: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the bugbear hits with it (included in the attack).

traits.name: Surprise Attack
traits.desc: If the bugbear surprises a creature and hits it with an attack during the first round of combat, the target takes an extra 7 (2d6) damage from the attack.

actions.name: Morningstar
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d8 + 2) piercing damage.

actions.name: Javelin
actions.desc: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (2d6 + 2) piercing damage.

tactics: Bugbears are ambush predators. They hide (surprisingly well with +6 Stealth), wait for the perfect moment, then hit with devastating Surprise Attack + Brute damage. They often lead goblin squads.
dmTips: A bugbear ambush is a great 'oh no' moment. Describe the signs of goblins throughout a dungeon, then have the bugbear boss drop from the ceiling or burst through a door. That first Surprise Attack hit of 2d8+2d6+2 will wake your players up FAST.

name: Owlbear

traits.name: Keen Sight and Smell
traits.desc: The owlbear has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight or smell.

actions.name: Multiattack
actions.desc: The owlbear makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its claws.

actions.name: Beak
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 10 (1d10 + 5) piercing damage.

actions.name: Claws
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 14 (2d8 + 5) slashing damage.

tactics: Owlbears are straightforward — they charge and maul. With Multiattack dealing up to 24 damage per round, they're dangerous but predictable. They fight to the death to protect their territory or nest.
dmTips: The owlbear is D&D's iconic weird creature. It's great for a tense forest encounter. Maybe the party stumbles into its territory near its nest. Do they fight, or try to sneak past? If there are eggs, the party might want to come back...

name: Troll

traits.name: Keen Smell
traits.desc: The troll has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

traits.name: Regeneration
traits.desc: The troll regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the troll takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the troll's next turn. The troll dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

actions.name: Multiattack
actions.desc: The troll makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

actions.name: Bite
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d6 + 4) piercing damage.

actions.name: Claw
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6 + 4) slashing damage.

tactics: Trolls are relentless attackers. With Regeneration, they can sustain tremendous damage and keep fighting. They fear fire and acid — the only things that can truly kill them. They'll focus attacks on whoever hurt them most recently.
dmTips: The troll is a great puzzle monster. Players who don't know about fire/acid vulnerability will panic when it keeps getting back up. Let them figure it out! An NPC could hint at it, or the troll could flinch from a nearby campfire.

name: Young Red Dragon
senses: Blindsight 30 ft., Darkvision 120 ft., passive Perception 18

actions.name: Multiattack
actions.desc: The dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

actions.name: Bite
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +10 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 17 (2d10 + 6) piercing damage plus 3 (1d6) fire damage.

actions.name: Claw
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +10 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d6 + 6) slashing damage.

actions.name: Fire Breath (Recharge 5-6)
actions.desc: The dragon exhales fire in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a DC 17 Dexterity saving throw, taking 56 (16d6) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

tactics: The dragon opens with Fire Breath, then uses flight to stay out of reach of melee fighters. It lands only to use Multiattack on isolated targets, then takes off again. It's arrogant and will taunt the party between attacks.
dmTips: This is BOSS FIGHT material. Young dragons are arrogant and sloppy — they think they're invincible. Give it a personality (vain, greedy, or angry about being 'young'). Let it monologue. Use the lair to create environmental hazards.

name: Basilisk

traits.name: Petrifying Gaze
traits.desc: If a creature starts its turn within 30 ft. of the basilisk and the two of them can see each other, the basilisk can force the creature to make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw if the basilisk isn't incapacitated. On a failed save, the creature magically begins to turn to stone and is restrained. On a success, the creature isn't affected. A creature that fails the save by 5 or more is instantly petrified.

actions.name: Bite
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) piercing damage plus 7 (2d6) poison damage.

tactics: The basilisk is slow but deadly. It relies on Petrifying Gaze to disable targets while it bites paralyzed victims. Players can avoid the gaze by choosing not to look at it (disadvantage on attacks). Smart parties will fight it blind.
dmTips: Foreshadow the basilisk with petrified animals and adventurers along the path. This creates dread and gives clever players a clue to avert their eyes. The basilisk's venom makes it dangerous even if they avoid the gaze.

name: Wraith
resistances: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, Thunder; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
conditionImmunities: Charmed, Exhaustion, Grappled, Paralyzed, Petrified, Poisoned, Prone, Restrained

traits.name: Incorporeal Movement
traits.desc: The wraith can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 (1d10) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

traits.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
traits.desc: While in sunlight, the wraith has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

actions.name: Life Drain
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 21 (4d8 + 3) necrotic damage. The target must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

actions.name: Create Specter
actions.desc: The wraith targets a humanoid within 10 feet of it that has been dead for no longer than 1 minute. The target's spirit rises as a specter in the space of its corpse or in the nearest unoccupied space. The specter is under the wraith's control.

tactics: The wraith flies through walls and attacks from unexpected angles. Life Drain is devastating — it lowers max HP! It will phase through solid objects to avoid attacks and strike from behind. If it kills a party member, it creates a specter mid-combat.
dmTips: Wraiths are terrifying because they can't be stopped by walls or doors. Use them in haunted locations where the party feels safe behind closed doors, then have it phase through. The HP reduction creates real stakes.

name: Hill Giant

actions.name: Multiattack
actions.desc: The giant makes two greatclub attacks.

actions.name: Greatclub
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +8 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 18 (3d8 + 5) bludgeoning damage.

actions.name: Rock
actions.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +8 to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. Hit: 21 (3d10 + 5) bludgeoning damage.

tactics: Hill giants are dumb brutes. They throw rocks at range, then charge in swinging. They'll grab anything large as a weapon — trees, carts, livestock. They fight until something hurts them badly, then try to flee while throwing rocks behind them.
dmTips: Hill giants are comic relief AND a serious threat. They're stupid hungry bullies. Maybe one demands tribute from a village — 'Bring food or giant smash!' — giving the party a chance to negotiate or fight.

name: Manticore

traits.name: Tail Spike Regrowth
traits.desc: The manticore has twenty-four tail spikes. Used spikes regrow when the manticore finishes a long rest.

actions.name: Multiattack
actions.desc: The manticore makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws or three with its tail spikes.

actions.name: Bite
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) piercing damage.

actions.name: Claw
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) slashing damage.

actions.name: Tail Spike
actions.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, range 100/200 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) piercing damage.

tactics: Manticores prefer to attack from the air, launching tail spikes from beyond melee range. They'll only land to use bite/claw attacks if their prey is nearly dead or immobilized. They're cowardly and will flee if reduced to half HP.
dmTips: Manticores can speak Common, which makes them unique — they'll talk during combat! They might offer deals, make threats, or mock the party. They also make great recurring villains if they escape the first encounter.

name: Adult Red Dragon
senses: Blindsight 60 ft., Darkvision 120 ft., passive Perception 23

traits.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
traits.desc: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

actions.name: Multiattack
actions.desc: The dragon can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

actions.name: Bite
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +14 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 19 (2d10 + 8) piercing damage plus 7 (2d6) fire damage.

actions.name: Claw
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +14 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 15 (2d6 + 8) slashing damage.

actions.name: Tail
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +14 to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. Hit: 17 (2d8 + 8) bludgeoning damage.

actions.name: Frightful Presence
actions.desc: Each creature of the dragon's choice within 120 feet must succeed on a DC 19 Wisdom saving throw or become frightened for 1 minute.

actions.name: Fire Breath (Recharge 5-6)
actions.desc: The dragon exhales fire in a 60-foot cone. Each creature must make a DC 21 Dexterity saving throw, taking 63 (18d6) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

legendaryActions.name: Detect
legendaryActions.desc: The dragon makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendaryActions.name: Tail Attack
legendaryActions.desc: The dragon makes a tail attack.

legendaryActions.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
legendaryActions.desc: The dragon beats its wings. Each creature within 10 ft. must succeed on a DC 22 Dexterity saving throw or take 15 (2d6 + 8) bludgeoning damage and be knocked prone. The dragon can then fly up to half its flying speed.

tactics: An adult red dragon is an apex predator with centuries of experience. It opens with Frightful Presence + Fire Breath, uses Wing Attack to reposition, and focuses on spellcasters first. It uses Legendary Resistance to shrug off the nastiest spells.
dmTips: This is an EPIC encounter. Build up to it over several sessions. The dragon should have a name, a personality, and a hoard. Use Legendary Actions between player turns to keep the dragon dangerous and unpredictable. This fight should feel like a war.

name: Ocular Tyrant

traits.name: Nullifying Gaze
traits.desc: The ocular tyrant's central eye creates an area of antimagic in a 150-foot cone. It decides which way the cone faces at the start of each of its turns. Spells and magical effects are suppressed within the cone.

actions.name: Bite
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 14 (4d6) piercing damage.

actions.name: Ocular Rays
actions.desc: The ocular tyrant fires three rays at random from its many eyes, choosing 1-3 targets within 120 ft. Each ray has a different devastating effect: charm, paralysis, fear, slowing, enervation, telekinesis, sleep, petrification, disintegration, or death. Targets must make a DC 16 saving throw (type varies by ray) or suffer the effect.

legendaryActions.name: Ocular Ray
legendaryActions.desc: The ocular tyrant uses one random ray from its eye stalks.

tactics: The ocular tyrant is paranoid and strategic. It aims its Nullifying Gaze at spellcasters to shut down their magic, then uses Ocular Rays on martial threats. It hovers in hard-to-reach positions and uses the environment (vertical shafts, over pits) to its advantage.
dmTips: This floating aberration is paranoid genius material. Its lair should be full of traps and surveillance. Roll the eye rays randomly for genuine tension. The nullifying gaze creates a unique tactical puzzle for the party.

name: Cerebral Devourer
skills: Arcana +7, Deception +6, Insight +6, Perception +6, Persuasion +6, Stealth +4
resistances: Magic (advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects)

traits.name: Magic Resistance
traits.desc: The cerebral devourer has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

traits.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
traits.desc: At will: detect thoughts, levitate; 1/day each: dominate monster, plane shift (self only)

actions.name: Tentacles
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 15 (2d10 + 4) psychic damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, it is grappled (escape DC 15) and must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw or be stunned until the grapple ends.

actions.name: Consume Intellect
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one incapacitated humanoid grappled by the cerebral devourer. Hit: 55 (10d10) piercing damage. If this reduces the target to 0 hit points, the cerebral devourer kills the target by consuming its mental essence.

actions.name: Psychic Blast (Recharge 5-6)
actions.desc: The cerebral devourer emits a wave of psychic energy in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw or take 22 (4d8 + 4) psychic damage and be stunned for 1 minute.

tactics: The cerebral devourer opens with Psychic Blast to stun as many targets as possible, then closes to use Tentacles on a stunned victim. If it can grapple a stunned target, it uses Consume Intellect on its next turn. It uses thralls (charmed minions) as shields.
dmTips: Cerebral devourers are TERRIFYING. The intellect consumption mechanic creates real fear. Build them up with hints: disappearances, people acting strangely (thralls), and psychic nightmares. This creature should feel like a horror movie villain.

name: Lich
languages: Common plus up to five other languages
immunities: Poison; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks

traits.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
traits.desc: If the lich fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

traits.name: Rejuvenation
traits.desc: If it has a phylactery, a destroyed lich gains a new body in 1d10 days, regaining all its hit points.

traits.name: Spellcasting
traits.desc: The lich is an 18th-level spellcaster (spell save DC 20, +12 to hit). It has access to the full wizard spell list. Key prepared spells include: power word kill, finger of death, disintegrate, globe of invulnerability, counterspell, fireball, shield, and magic missile.

actions.name: Paralyzing Touch
actions.desc: Melee Spell Attack: +12 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 10 (3d6) cold damage. The target must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution saving throw or be paralyzed for 1 minute.

legendaryActions.name: Frightening Gaze (Costs 2 Actions)
legendaryActions.desc: The lich fixes its gaze on one creature it can see within 10 feet. The target must succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw against this magic or become frightened for 1 minute.

legendaryActions.name: Disrupt Life (Costs 3 Actions)
legendaryActions.desc: Each non-undead creature within 20 feet must make a DC 18 Constitution saving throw, taking 21 (6d6) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half on success.

tactics: A lich is the ultimate spellcaster villain. It opens combat with globe of invulnerability, then counterspells enemy casters while blasting with fireball and disintegrate. It uses Legendary Resistance to ignore dangerous effects and its legendary actions to maintain pressure between turns.
dmTips: The lich is an END-GAME villain. It should be the BBEG (Big Bad Evil Guy) of a campaign. The key mechanic: the phylactery. Players must find and destroy it, or the lich will keep coming back. The lich should be intelligent, patient, and always have a contingency plan.
